results.title: The Family Law Production stills
results.brief_description: Based on Benjamin Law’s 2010 book, The Family Law was the first Australian TV show to focus on an Asian Australian family. While it explores familiar stories about an everyday family, it offers a unique perspective on what it means to be Australian today.

details.label: Curatorial section
display_values: The Story of the Moving Image → Moving Australia → MA-11. Screen Australia Showcase

results.title: Spellbound Concerto record
results.brief_description: Though the theremin is most commonly associated with science fiction, it was first used in Alfred Hitchcock’s Spellbound (1945). For a dream sequence designed by Surrealist artist Salvador Dali, composer Miklós Rózsa used the theremin’s strange reverberations to produce unease and psychological tension.
results.description: Though the theremin is most commonly associated with science fiction, it was first used in Alfred Hitchcock’s Spellbound (1945). results.title: The Brown Box replica
results.brief_description:
The Brown Box was reproduced for the Renewal project - facilitated by Mark Baer (Trustee of the Ralph Baer Trust). This object is in working condition tested by Mark Baer 2 November 2019.

Text from Arieh Offman, Curator, Videogames, ACMI - “The Brown Box prototype, created and patented by Ralph Baer, was the forerunner to the first home console ever released, the Magnavox Odyssey (currently held by ACMI), and development began in 1966. It was originally called the ‘TV Game Unit #7’ and received its better known name ‘Brown Box’ from the faux wood grain self-adhesive vinyl that was attached to the prototype to make it more attractive to potential investor. The game unit could play multiple programs / games, and this was achieved by flipping the physical switches on the front of the unit – these included games such as ping pong, checkers, and four different sports games. The Brown Box was the seventh version of this prototype, with multiple versions coming before and after it with alterations to hardware and output.”

Description from the Smithsonian Museum:
“This machine paved the way for the video games of today.
In 1967, Ralph Baer and his colleagues at Sanders Associates, Inc. developed a prototype for the first multiplayer, multiprogram video game system. Since Sanders hoped to license the technology for a commercial venture, Baer understood that the games had to be fun or investors and consumers would not be interested. In an oral history interview (copies available in the Archives Center at the National Museum of American History), Ralph Baer recalled, “The minute we played ping-pong, we knew we had a product. Before that we weren’t too sure.”Originally called TV Game Unit #7, much like the “Pump Unit” before it, it became far better known by its nickname, “The Brown Box.” The name comes from the brown wood-grain, self-adhesive vinyl used to make the prototype look more attractive to potential investors. The “Brown Box,” though only a prototype, had basic features that most video games consoles still have today: two controls and a multigame program system.The “Brown Box” could be programmed to play a variety of games by flipping the switches along the front of the unit, as can be seen in the picture. Program cards were used to show which switches needed to be set for specific games. “Brown Box” games included ping-pong, checkers, four different sports games, target shooting with the use of a lightgun and a golf putting game, which required the use of a special attachment. Sanders licensed the “Brown Box” to Magnavox, which released the system as the Magnavox Odyssey in 1972.” https://americanhistory.si.edu/collections/search/object/nmah_1301997
results.description:
In 1966, the father of videogames, Ralph Baer, began developing the Brown Box prototype, the forerunner to the first home console ever released, the Magnavox Odyssey.

Originally called the ‘TV Game Unit #7’, Baer’s prototype became better known as the Brown Box because of its faux wood-grain vinyl. It ran multiple programs and games – including ping-pong, checkers and four different sports games – which were controlled by flipping the switches on the front of the unit.
description_for_label:
In 1966, the father of videogames, Ralph Baer, began developing the Brown Box prototype, the forerunner to the first home console ever released, the Magnavox Odyssey.

Originally called the ‘TV Game Unit #7’, Baer’s prototype became better known as the Brown Box because of its faux wood-grain vinyl. It ran multiple programs and games – including ping-pong, checkers and four different sports games – which were controlled by flipping the switches on the front of the unit.

results.title: Crash zone. Vol. 2. Season 1. Eps 06-09
results.creator_credit: Stephen Johnson, Pino Amenta, Ray Boseley, Esben Storm, Patricia Edgar, Disney Channel Australia and Australian Children's Television Foundation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Crash zone”.
Episode 6: When Bec begins a ‘Net romance’ the boys are sceptical. Their worst fears are realised when they discover that it is Virgil, their A.I. friend that is wooing her. Episode 7: Bec and Pi have differences of opinion when they design a game for girls about teenage romance. The resulting mess causes the team to acknowledge they still have a lot to learn about emotions and life. Episode 8: When a reporter arrives at Catalyst to do a story on the testers, they have suspicions she may be a spy. Pi, who has led the gang to believe she is a street kid, is unmasked when her mother tracks her to the company. Cast includes Paul Pantano, Cassandra Magrath, Nikolai Nikolaeff, Frances Wang, Damien Bodie, Nicki Wendt and Matthew Parkinson. Teaching resources can be found at: http://www.actf.com.au/learning_centre_new/Learning_frameset.htm Accompanying website at: www.crashzone.tv

results.title: Continuity photos

constellations_other.name: Creating characters with Great costumes
constellations_other.description: Emma Fryer's costume design for The Great took inspiration from both accurate finery of the period, and contemporary designs of fashion houses like Dior. The resulting costumes evolve with the characters.

results.title: Bill Onus hosting Alcheringa
results.brief_description: To Bill Onus, sharing his culture was an act of resistance and reclamation of power. Through Forgotten People(1967) and Alcheringa (1962), Bill demonstrated his ongoing commitment to self-representation through screen culture.

constellations_other.name: Connecting through film
constellations_other.description: Film acts like a time capsule to our collective past. Capturing our most treasured moments with family has never been more accessible, with technology right at our fingers.

results.title_for_label: Film still of Bill Onus hosting Alcheringa, 1962
